title: Space Force, Parental Leave and More: Spending Bills Bring an Array of Overhauls
summary: President Trump signs spending package to fund the government and defense-policy bill. President Trump on Friday signed a nearly $1.4 trillion spending package to fund the government through the end of the fiscal year and a $738 billion annual defense-policy bill, which both include a range of policy provisions that will affect millions of Americans. Here are some of the highlights:

title: When Congress Buys Time to Finish a Budget, the Price Is Uncertainty
summary: This week's spending deal comes after temporary measures extended last year's funding for months-an increasingly common tactic that can leave programs in limbo. WASHINGTON-The last-minute deal to avoid a shutdown and fund the government through September is symptomatic of a start-stop spending pattern that has bedeviled Congress for more than 40 years. Don't expect that to change anytime soon.

title: Trump Administration Waives Tighter Rules for Less Efficient Lightbulbs
summary: Energy Department blocks rising standards that would have phased out more-energy-intensive incandescent bulbs. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is intervening to protect old-fashioned incandescent lightbulbs from rising energy-efficiency standards, part of a deregulatory push that 16 states have already challenged to uphold their efforts to fight climate change.

title: DHS Watchdog Finds No Wrongdoing in Deaths of Two Migrant Children
summary: The deaths in December 2018 came amid border crisis, raised questions about medical care and treatment. WASHINGTON-The Department of Homeland Security's internal watchdog found no wrongdoing or misconduct by immigration officials in the deaths of two migrant children last December.

title: Washington's Seven-Layer Fake
summary: The unreality of Comey and Pelosi's Washington.. Former FBI Director James Comey is sticking with his story that he was only vaguely aware of the details involving the request for historic political surveillance that he approved and certified. Meanwhile, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's rush to overturn the results of the 2016 election has come to a sudden halt.

title: U.S. Invites China for Talks on Nuclear Arms
summary: Trump administration wants to push toward a U.S.-Russia-China deal, but China has shown little interest. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration said Friday that it had formally invited China to begin talks on arms control, a move the White House hopes will be a first step toward an agreement that will cover all U.S., Russian and Chinese nuclear weapons.

title: PG&E, Groups Reach Agreement on Rate Increases
summary: Any rate increases by the California utility would still need approval from regulator, administrative judges. Pacific Gas & Electric Co., the utility arm of PG&E Corp. , has reached an agreement with several customer advocacy, labor and safety groups that calls for state regulators to allow the company to pass on to consumers some rate increases to fund safety improvements and other wildfire-prevention efforts.

title: Trump Drops Threat to Levy Tariffs on Brazilian Steel and Aluminum
summary: Move comes after Trump and Brazilian President Bolsonaro spoke Friday. WASHINGTON-President Trump dropped a threat to levy tariffs on Brazilian steel and aluminum after the two leaders spoke Friday.

title: Boeing's Crisis Spreads Beyond MAX
summary: Troubled Starliner space launch and new tensions with airlines and suppliers hit aerospace giant. Boeing Co. botched the first demonstration flight of a long-awaited space capsule and said it would suspend taking major 737 MAX parts from its biggest supplier, setbacks that pushed the aerospace giant deeper into crisis Friday.

title: An ObamaCare Judicial Morass
summary: Democrats get new ammunition as an ill-fated lawsuit drags on.. Even as Democratic presidential candidacies implode over Medicare for All, Republican state attorneys general and the Trump Administration are handing the left a political lifeline with an overbroad attack on ObamaCare in the courts. On Wednesday the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals ensured this will drag on as it struck down the individual mandate and asked a district-court judge to determine if other parts of the law have to go too.

title: Robert Mueller's Dossier Dodge
summary: Why did the special counsel not tell America that Christopher Steele's information was false?. In her public order Tuesday, Presiding Judge Rosemary Collyer of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court didn't mention Robert Mueller. But her stinging rebuke of the FBI for abusing the FISA process to obtain a warrant to spy on Carter Page invites the question: How could the special counsel have ignored the Steele dossier?

title: A $900 Bottle of Hypocrisy
summary: Are you now, or have you ever been, in a wine cave?. Few political spectacles are more amusing than watching Democrats who are millionaires attempting to deny that they consort with other millionaires, much less with dastardly billionaires. This was on extended display at Thursday's presidential debate, and it offers a lesson about money and politics.

title: Facebook, Twitter Remove AI-Powered Fake Accounts With Pro-Trump Messages
summary: Online campaign involved hundreds of accounts and more than $9 million spent on Facebook advertising. Facebook Inc. and Twitter Inc. have taken down a global network of fake accounts used in a coordinated campaign to push pro-Trump political messages, including some that used artificial intelligence tools to try to mask the behavior, the companies and outside research firms they worked with said on Friday.

title: Nasdaq Prevails in Lawsuit Over Stolen ETF
summary: Judge rules against ETF Managers Group, resolving long legal battle. Nasdaq Inc. prevailed in its lawsuit against a former business partner it accused of stealing more than $1 billion in exchange-traded funds, including a popular cybersecurity ETF.

summary: From Facebook to Uber, newly appointed marketing chiefs had lots of work to do. title: 'Richard III: The Self-Made King' Review: The Road to Bosworth
summary: Was the last Plantagenet monarch the malevolent, murderous schemer of Shakespeare's play or a fair and honorable ruler whose good name was posthumously blackened to justify the seizure of his throne by Henry Tudor?. More than 500 years after he was killed fighting for his crown at the Battle of Bosworth, King Richard III remains one of the most controversial figures in English history. Although he reigned for only 26 months, from July 1483 to August 1485, his reputation continues to polarize opinion. Was the last Plantagenet monarch the malevolent, murderous schemer of Shakespeare's play or a fair and honorable ruler whose good name was posthumously blackened to justify the seizure of his throne by Henry Tudor?

title: Trump Administration Backs Bayer in Weedkiller Court Fight
summary: EPA, Justice Department file brief supporting company's arguments that Roundup weedkiller didn't require cancer warning. The Trump administration is backing Bayer AG in the German chemical maker's high-stakes court fight over the world's most widely used weedkiller.

title: Nearly 100 Arrested in Long Island Probe of MS-13 Street Gang
summary: Takedown effectively ends gang's operations in New York state, officials say. Nearly 100 alleged MS-13 members and associates have been arrested on murder-conspiracy, drug-trafficking and weapons-possession charges as part of a 23-month investigation into the violent international street gang, New York's Suffolk County district attorney said Friday.

title: Behind the Biotech Stock Rally: New Deals and Easing Political Worries
summary: Nasdaq Biotechnology Index has gained 22% so far this quarter, outpacing S&P 500's 8.2% gain. Shares of biotech companies have surged in recent months, boosted by innovation, a spate of deals and easing worries about political risks.

summary: Regulators focusing in part on first day of trading in wide-ranging review of IPOs. summary: Major U.S. indexes bolstered by signs of economic strength and easing trade tensions. U.S. stocks closed out the week at records, powered higher by new signs of economic strength that have followed a calming in trade tensions.

summary: Court system's disciplinary panel given powers to fine and fire judges for political activities. WARSAW-Poland's parliament passed a law giving a judicial disciplinary panel the power to fine and dismiss judges for political activities, overriding complaints from European Union officials and protesters who have called the law authoritarian.

title: After Trump's Impeachment, Pelosi Ends Year With Strong Hold on Party
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-Nancy Pelosi is ending the first year of her second stint as House speaker with more support from her caucus and outside liberal groups than she started with, ironically because of how she handled a task she long resisted.

title: DOJ, FCC Support T-Mobile, Sprint in Antitrust Fight With States
summary: Federal officials criticize states' challenge in brief filed near the end of antitrust trial. The Justice Department and Federal Communications Commission on Friday criticized a lawsuit by state attorneys general that seeks to block the merger of T-Mobile US Inc. and Sprint Corp. , adding the federal government's voice to an unusual case on its final day of testimony.

title: Boeing's First Test Flight of Uncrewed Space Capsule Stuck In Wrong Orbit
summary: Improper fuel burn ends up causing NASA to scratch plans to link up Starliner vehicle with orbiting space station. Boeing Co. 's initial test flight of its Starliner space capsule without astronauts on board was stranded in the wrong orbit, scuttling a plan to dock with the international space station and dealing a high-profile setback to U.S. space-exploration ambitions.

title: New Report Adds to Evidence Vitamin E Oil at Fault in Vaping Illnesses
summary: A new report found lung samples from 48 out of 51 vaping patients contained oil associated with the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released its strongest evidence to date that vitamin E acetate is the major culprit in more than 2,500 serious lung illnesses tied to vaping over the past several months.

title: Guatemala Is Set to Finalize Deal With U.S. to Accept Mexican Asylum Seekers
summary: After meeting between Trump and Morales, Mexican as well as Brazilian migrants are likely to be transferred to Central American country. Guatemala is set to finalize within days a deal to expand its asylum agreement with the U.S. to begin accepting Mexican migrants sent from the southern U.S. border, U.S. and Guatemalan officials familiar with the talks said.

title: Volcker Knew the Meaning of Public Service
summary: He felt that our government is only as good as the people who believe in its institutions and dedicate themselves to the higher ideals of service.. I worked under Paul Volcker many years ago as a junior staffer at the Federal Reserve Board when I started my career in Washington ("Paul Adolph Volcker," Review & Outlook, Dec. 10). Like so many of my colleagues, I came to respect and admire him for his fortitude, tireless work ethic and dedication to the Fed.

title: U.S. Innovation, a Cold Case: Dead or Alive?
summary: If the manufacturing isn't happening in America, the innovation won't either.. Mene Ukueberuwa is right to spot the death of U.S. innovation ("American Innovation, a Murder Mystery," Dec. 14), but it's no mystery what killed it. Almost all inventors are deeply involved in their field of technology, the use and development of products in that field, and ultimately the manufacture of finished products. This can't be taught in the universities; it requires the kind of capital used in the manufacturing and product-development process itself. And if that manufacturing isn't happening in America, the innovation won't either.

title: Trump Administration Awards Migrant Detention Contracts Days Before California Would Ban Them
summary: ICE refutes criticism that it is trying to evade new state law with last-minute move. The federal agency in charge of immigrant detention has awarded multiyear contracts for private companies to run facilities in California just over a week before a new state law forbidding them goes into effect.

title: The Questions Democrats Don't Ask and Can't Answer
summary: Have we really thought through the implications of open borders? Will it be counterproductive to tax corporations and "the rich" into oblivion? Is the Green New Deal feasible?. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "Who Can Beat Trump?" (Declarations, Dec. 14): That's the wrong question. Democrats might have a chance to beat President Trump if they ask some better ones. They'll need to ask real, tough questions, like why they lost the election in 2016. The tall tale of Russian collusion won't cut it as an answer.

title: This Takes 'Radical Chic' Literally-and Much Too Far
summary: Why highlight Shigenobu Twilight, a fragrance inspired by Fusako Shigenobu, the leader and founder of the Japanese Red Army?. It highlighted Shigenobu Twilight, a fragrance inspired by Fusako Shigenobu, the leader and founder of the Japanese Red Army. The JRA was a communist terrorist group responsible for numerous bombings and kidnappings, dozens of deaths and hundreds of injuries.

title: A World of Emotion in Two Hands
summary: Verrocchio's ''Lady With Flowers' is a revolutionary work in its composition and captures both the sitter's appearance and her inner life.. 'Verrocchio: Sculptor and Painter of Renaissance Florence," at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, has been widely acclaimed for having brought a great master out from the shadow of his renowned onetime apprentice Leonardo da Vinci. Nowhere is Verrocchio's extraordinary talent more in evidence than in the marble "Lady With Flowers" (c. 1475/1480). So fresh, animated and lifelike is it that you feel you are sharing space not with a sculpture but with an actual presence. In part this is because, instead of creating a static, remote figure, he has depicted her caught in the flux of time. Before it returns to the Bargello Museum in Florence after the show closes on Jan. 12, 2020, anyone who can should make an effort to see it, and anyone who already has should see it again.

title: Second Officer Dies in Shooting Near Russian Security-Services Building
summary: Suspect, killed by police, is resident of Moscow region; motive is under investigation. MOSCOW-A second federal security service officer wounded in a shootout in the center of the Russian capital has died and the suspect has been identified.

title: Despite Initial Trade Deal, Analysts Still Project Plentiful Crude in 2020
summary: Projections reassessed after U.S.-China accord, OPEC cuts. Energy-market analysts are adjusting their oil supply-demand forecasts after an initial U.S.-China trade deal and OPEC supply cuts, but many still see global oil output keeping up with consumption next year.

title: A New 'Nutcracker'
summary: At the Joyce, the Christmas favorite takes an engagingly unfamiliar form with a soundtrack by Duke Ellington and Billy Strayhorn..

title: Farewell to the 2010s, the Uneasy Decade of Populism
summary: The economy grew and grew, even as tech stalled and anxiety rose. Like anniversaries, the ends of decades have become a convenient excuse for those of us in the media to sell more of our product by offering grand declarations about the passage of history. Unlike anniversaries, which at least memorialize events that happened in a particular time and place, decade retrospectives are entirely confected. It's a silly conceit to think that history neatly divides into 10-year periods that start with a zero and end in a nine.

title: Pelosi Invites Trump to Give State of the Union Speech Feb. 4
summary: The address before congress could potentially take place during president's impeachment trial. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has invited President Trump to give a State of the Union address next year, a speech before Congress that could potentially take place during his impeachment trial.

title: Marijuana's Money Man
summary: A Canadian banker who invests in some of the same companies he advises is helping U.S. cannabis firms reach for the jackpot. Graham Saunders is a man in high demand.

title: Cadets, Midshipmen Weren't Flashing 'White Power' Signs, Probe Finds
summary: West Point cadets, Navy midshipmen were playing pranks during Army-Navy game and had no extremist intent, according to review. Cadets and midshipmen who flashed "OK" hand signs on national television during the annual Army-Navy football game on Dec. 14 didn't intend to convey extremist messages, but were playing a game that involves the use of the gesture, according to findings of a military review released Friday.

title: British Prosecutors to Charge Wife of U.S. Diplomat in Car Crash Death
summary: Case involving 19-year-old motorcyclist Harry Dunn presents legal and diplomatic test for the two allies' close relationship. British prosecutors said they have decided to charge the wife of a U.S. diplomat with "causing death by dangerous driving" after she was involved in a car crash that killed a 19-year-old motorcyclist, presenting a legal and diplomatic test for the two allies' close relationship.

title: Telling the American Story
summary: A series of historical canvases by Jacob Lawrence is reunited for the first time. The African-American painter Jacob Lawrence (1917-2000) catapulted to fame at the age of 23 thanks to "The Migration Series" (1940-41), a suite of 60 paintings tracing the mass exodus of blacks from the American South. In 1949, he set his sights on a similarly ambitious project: a group of paintings that would offer a broad retelling of the nation's early history. "Struggle: From the History of the American People" (1954-56) took him five years to research and two more to paint. In 1954, Lawrence said that he hoped the paintings might "enlighten those who come in contact with them of the struggles, contributions and ingenuity of the American people." But the series was never acquired by a museum, and over time its 30 paintings were dispersed, largely to private collections.

title: After String of Rare Cancer Cases, Pennsylvania Investigates Potential Link to Fracking
summary: Resume Subscription. CECIL TOWNSHIP, Pa.-An increase in the number of teens and young adults diagnosed with a rare cancer in the southwest corner of Pennsylvania has caused the state to look for a link between fracking and the disease.

title: India's Muslims Push Back Against Modi Government
summary: Citizenship law is viewed as having far more impact than ruling party's other policies affecting Muslim community. NEW DELHI-Indian Muslims are stepping off the sidelines to join the political fray, driven by fears their status as citizens has never been more threatened and encouraged by the numbers of non-Muslims joining them in opposing a new citizenship law.

title: Consumer Spending Strengthens as Year Winds Down
summary: U.S. household spending, a key driver of the economy, rose in November, along with higher income and more positive views of the economy. WASHINGTON-Consumers boosted spending as they headed into the end of the year, buoyed by a rise in income and an optimistic outlook for the U.S. economy.

title: The Consumer Lives On, but Carefully
summary: With Americans unwilling to run down savings and the job market slowing, consumer spending has everything to do with wages. The only way to get people to spend more money these days is to pay them more.

's production halt of its embattled plane, according to people familiar with the matter.

summary: Company's losses are growing in a weak steel market. United States Steel Corp. said it would idle most of a mill near Detroit as the company's losses mount in a weak domestic steel market.

summary: Boeing recently paused production of best-selling jet as recertification timeline slips.

summary: The recently merged company is looking to broaden its programming holdings and Miramax has a library of well-known films. ViacomCBS Inc. said it is acquiring a 49% stake in movie and television production company Miramax Pictures from BeIN Media Group for $375 million.

title: A Genetic Test Led Seven Women in One Family to Have Major Surgery. Then the Odds Changed.
summary: Resume Subscription. When she was in her early 30s, Katy Mathes decided to check her cancer risk. A genetic test showed a mutation on a BRCA gene, which significantly raises a person's lifetime risk of developing hereditary breast or ovarian cancer.

title: Who Needs Triple Axels and Toe Loops-Give Us 'Compulsory Figures'
summary: Resume Subscription. Thirty years ago, the International Skating Union made a crowd-pleasing change to figure skating: It kicked out of competitions a segment known as compulsory figures, which required skaters to etch patterns on the ice with their blades, then trace them over and over again.

title: 'Irving Berlin: New York Genius' Review: They Say It's Wonderful
summary: Irving Berlin's energy, versatility and sheer knack for creating catchy tunes helped the poor Jewish immigrant from Siberia become synonymous with American song.. To begin with, he lived forever-the only major American popular songwriter to become a centenarian. In addition, he never stopped working; though his glory days were long behind him, he was still penning lyrics and planning songs in 1988, his 100th year. Through sheer amplitude, Irving Berlin presents a forbidding subject to biographers, though many attempts have been made. He wasn't yet 40 when the first life story appeared.

title: 'Abraham Joshua Heschel' Review: A Prophet for Postwar America
summary: The most prominent rabbi in postwar America, Abraham Joshua Heschel turned out to be uniquely gifted at bringing the authority of Jewish tradition to bear on the country's problems-from spiritual apathy and conformism to the civil-rights movement and the Vietnam War.. When Abraham Joshua Heschel was born in Warsaw in 1907, his future was easy to predict. He was destined to become a rabbi, a Jewish community leader, a thinker about God and Torah. After all, his family tree was full of rabbis-his father, both his grandfathers and so on back to the 18th century, when his ancestors were among the early leaders of Hasidism, the pietistic revival movement than transformed Eastern European Judaism.

title: French Telecom Giant Found Guilty of 'Moral Harassment' Linked to Suicides
'On Mercy' and 'When Should Law Forgive?' Review: Our Most God-Like Power
summary: Two books by accomplished scholars ask: Do forgiveness and mercy have a place in law?. American public life is full of disputes about justice and forgiveness. Take the Dreamers-the nearly 700,000 young adults who came from Mexico and elsewhere as children, did not obtain citizenship or permanent resident status, and have been in legal limbo since President Obama signed an executive order giving them temporary legal status in 2012. Depending on whom you talk to, these immigrants should either be deported immediately or given full citizenship.

title: 'John Henry Newman' Review: A Heart That Speaks to Hearts
summary: Newman was not a Victorian but a Romantic, less than six years younger than Keats, though he would outlive him by decades.. John Henry Newman was and is an exceptional figure. This October he was declared a saint by the Catholic Church, the first English saint created in half a century. For much of Newman's life, he struggled with unpopularity, misunderstanding and vilification from his various opponents. He was the most distinguished and the most original English theologian since the Middle Ages, but he was disliked and distrusted by many in the Catholic Church, as well as by the English Protestants and unbelievers whom he had horrified by his defection, in 1845, from the Church of England. Yet when he died, aged 89 in 1890, in an England still generally anti-Catholic, he had become, as Eamon Duffy says in this splendid book, an unlikely "national treasure" to whom Tennyson and Matthew Arnold-by no means Catholics-had written polite but puzzled tributes.

title: Five Best: Howard Jacobson on Teachers in Fiction
summary: The author, most recently, of 'Live a Little,' recommends works that educate about education.. By Charles Dickens (1865)

title: Fiction: Shadow Plays Projected on a Paper Screen
summary: A Greek-Irish story-teller at the turn of the 20th century preserved the eeriest folk tales of a rapidly Westernizing Japan.. In Kyoto, in the 16th century, according to legend, there lived an old street preacher named Kwashin Koji who made his living by exhibiting an amazingly realistic painting of the Buddhist conception of hell. So vivid was the painting that the city's ruler became determined to have it, whether by purchase or theft. But each time the work came into his hands, the image appeared altered, either losing the luster and detail that made it remarkable or simply vanishing from the scroll. Finally Kwashin Koji was brought in to explain: "In any picture of real excellence there must be a ghost; and such a picture, having a will of its own, may refuse to be separated from the person who gave it life, or even from its rightful owner. There are many stories to prove that really great pictures have souls."

title: Children's Books: Just the Facts, Please
summary: Notable nonfiction works for readers of all ages.. On the night of Sept. 17, 1940, the cry of Torpedos los! went up on a German submarine prowling the North Atlantic. Two underwater missiles shot toward the lead ship in a British convoy-and missed. Had the U-boat captain known that the SS City of Benares was transporting 100 child evacuees to Canada, he might have called off the assault. But he didn't, and so, moments later, he sent a third torpedo streaking to its target.

title: 'A Month in Siena' Review: The Consolation of Art
summary: A medieval city's famous paintings help the author come to terms with his grief.. In 1990, when Hisham Matar was a 19-year-old undergraduate in London, his father, an active opponent of the regime of Moammar Gadhafi, was abducted in Cairo and flown back to Libya. "He was imprisoned and gradually, like salt dissolving in water, was made to vanish." His son never found out what became of him.

title: Mysteries: Murder in Bleak Midwinter
summary: Anne Perry annually treats fans of her Victorian mysteries to a Christmas adventure. This year Victor Narraway, former head of London Special Branch, completes one more secret mission while at an old friend's estate.. Readers of Anne Perry's Victorian-era mystery novels look forward to her annual Christmas stories: slim volumes that lace suspense into fables of morality and redemption. This year's offering, "A Christmas Gathering" (Ballantine, 193 pages, $20), is a tale of violence and espionage in a remote English country house.

title: 'Fifth Sun' Review: The Aztec Achievement
summary: A new view of the empire upended by Cortés shows how heavily the Spanish invaders depended afterward on local rulers.. From the distance of five centuries we often look back to the conquest of Mexico as an all-out defeat for Aztec civilization, a victory by scrappy Spanish conquistadors over the awed and unprepared forces of Moctezuma. Camilla Townsend's fine "Fifth Sun: A New History of the Aztecs" shows us that this picture is simply wrong, the result of one-sided accounts and incomplete narratives. Ms. Townsend has combed the extraordinary accounts of the early colonial era written by indigenous historians to paint a far more complex picture of persistence by the Aztecs and their descendants. It is a vivid account of what Aztec writers and chroniclers had to say about their own history and of a world decimated through constant change and loss.

title: Christmas Invented Secular World, and They've Been at Odds Ever Since
summary: Resume Subscription. Nothing screams Christmas quite like Santa doing cocaine. This, at any rate, seems to be the thinking of FUN Wear, a company that has been offering, among other items of festive clothing, a sweater emblazoned with the shoutline "LET IT SNOW." Just in case there is any doubt as to the intended pun, a grinning Santa, his pupils popping, is shown with three neat lines in front of him. "We all know how snow works," winks the product description. "It's white, powdery and the best snow comes straight from South America."

title: Japan Tries to Thwart Collapse of Iran Nuclear Deal

title: American Democracy Depends on the 'Deep State'
summary: Professional bureaucrats devoted to the public interest, not to a political boss, are crucial to fighting corruption and upholding the rule of law. For years, conservatives have been railing against the growth of the "administrative state," a mass of faceless and unaccountable bureaucrats allegedly holding tyrannical power over ordinary citizens. Since the election of Donald Trump in 2016 and the launch of several investigations of his administration, this complaint has morphed into even sharper attacks on America's so-called "deep state": unelected officials who are supposedly partisan Democrats ready to do anything to undermine the Trump presidency. Such charges were hurled against the civil servants called to testify in the House's impeachment hearings, including top career diplomats such as Marie Yovanovitch and Bill Taylor and National Security Council experts such as Fiona Hill and Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman.

title: Perks and Recreation: These $400,000 RVs Are Built for 'Overlanding'

title: The Fund That Does a Lot by Doing Nothing
summary: Voya Corporate Leaders Trust hasn't made a major change to its portfolio since 1935, but it's still going strong. Let me tell you about a mutual fund that bought a few stocks 84 years ago and hasn't moved a muscle ever since.

title: U.K. Parliament Backs Johnson's Push For January Brexit
summary: Vote a significant but not final step to allow U.K. to leave EU on Jan. 31. LONDON-Britain's new Parliament voted overwhelmingly Friday to back Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit accord, a significant step toward the country's departure from the European Union on Jan. 31.

title: With Brexit Looming, U.K. Picks Veteran as Central Bank Chief
summary: Andrew Bailey is set to take over from Mark Carney as Bank of England governor in March. title: Why Running Outdoors in Winter Is a Killer Strategy
summary: Winter workouts can actually help boost performance, endurance and speed come spring. Here, the equipment you need to up your mileage as temperatures drop. WHEN THE weather outside is frightful, you might think the last thing you'd want to do is lace up some running sneakers and jog out into the snow and ice. Hopping on the treadmill in your cozy basement seems both saner and more strategic. Not necessarily: As long as you have the proper gear, cold weather runs can actually offer a more intense workout that will help you run faster and longer when warm weather returns.

title: Employers Move to Attract Tech Talent Before Graduation
summary: Businesses are recruiting hires while they are still students, while ramping up training programs for current employees. summary: Actors Tony Shalhoub, Marin Hinkle, Michael Zegen and Stephanie Hsu on the family dynamics of the Amazon comedy's third season: "I'm a parent in real life-and my heart is forever in my hand, you know?". In the third season of Amazon 's The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel, there's a flashy trip to Miami, wherein Miriam's parents, Tony Shalhoub's Abe and Marin Hinkle's Rose, join their comedian daughter for a much-needed trip out of New York City. As the series heads further into the politically turbulent 1960s-and deeper into the comedy industry for Miriam (Rachel Brosnahan)-there's a widening of the show's outlook, too; more issues than just the family's life are coming into focus.

title: The Dallas Cowboys Are Built on a Backup Plan
summary: The team surrounded Dak Prescott with as many coaches as possible who were backup quarterbacks. Now that coaching staff is under fire with the season on the line.. It's especially true this year because Prescott happens to be due an enormous contract extension from a team that is falling short of the raging expectations it carried into the season.

title: Democrats Pressure GOP Over Unfunded Military Projects
summary: Sens. Martha McSally, Cory Gardner face attacks over funds diverted from states for border wall; Wisconsin Democrats confront voter purge. Democrats are eager to highlight projects that lost funding in states and districts represented by vulnerable Republicans. Top targets include Colorado Sen. Cory Gardner, whose state lost millions in funding for Colorado Springs' Peterson Air Force Base, and Sen. Martha McSally, whose state lost $30 million for a southern Arizona Army base.
